title: university isnt the only option for a level students
story: After two years of studying for A-levels, thousands of young people will find out if their hard work has paid off.Whether they’re aiming to start an apprenticeship, take a place at university, or go straight into a good job, there are plenty of opportunities awaiting them – and the prospects are high.The jobs market has transformed since 2010, with over 3.3 million more people in work – on average that’s over 1,000 more people in a job each and every day.And, since 2010, the majority of that employment growth has been in both full-time and permanent roles.Only yesterday, the latest official statistics showed that unemployment has fallen to 4% - which means it’s the lowest it’s been since the 1970s.To put that into context, someone would be well into their 50s today to remember a time of lower unemployment.And this transformation of the jobs landscape is being led by our young people. Yesterdays employment figures revealed that the proportion of young people unemployed (and not in full-time education) is now at a record low of 4.7% for our country - and far lower than for many other developed countries.It sends a significant message out about the drive and innovation of our young people, and the opportunities that our economy offers to them and their future.With our welfare changes this country can now be powered forward by this young generation.Since 2010, youth unemployment has fallen by over 45%, giving 130,000 more young people a job, and a future.Add the fact that wages are on the up and there are more than 829,000 vacancies nationwide, it’s clear that young people are entering the best jobs market in a decade.On average, the number of vacancies has increased by 4,280 each month over the last year, and those vacancies span from construction to technology.So when young people this week are deciding on their next steps, they can think big as there are plenty of opportunities out there for them, from a job with career progression, to taking up an apprenticeship.Look at Daisy, who turned down five university offers to work at global engineering firm JCB designing new equipment, and she didn’t have to go to university to get there.I’m forever being told, and intrinsically understand, that people want to study at different times in their lives, often inspired to do so when they see the practical benefits of their studies.That’s why so many people prefer, and do better, getting a job first and then studying for exams while they work.Even over the last few decades, how the world of education and work are linked has shifted dramatically. People no longer have one job for life, and lifelong learning is becoming more and more commonplace as people dip in and out of education.Many more people up-skill and retrain throughout their career – and this is how the future jobs market will remain vibrant and strong.And when I speak to employers up and down the country, from manufacturers to marketers, what they want are young people with the right attitude, prepared to work and learn. As they say, ‘if you’ve the will, we can give you the skill’.So when young people this week are deciding their next steps, the academic route isn’t the only option.You can now become a solicitor, an accountant or even a nuclear engineer through the apprenticeship route, earning as you learn and without the cost of going to University. Studying a Higher Apprenticeship gives an average wage boost of £150,000 over a working life.When I speak to young people around the country, I’m impressed with the confidence and self-assuredness with which they look to the future, and the range of options they consider beyond traditional routes.Im certainly no job snob. Life teaches you its not where you come from, its where you get to, and work is exactly the same.You can start anywhere and get to the top as Im repeatedly being told by our countrys top entrepreneurs.Top performers in their fields such as Debbie Moore, Jean-Christophe Novelli, Deborah Meaden and Jo Malone, did not go to university and are just a handful of the individuals who show that with drive and determination you can succeed by treading your own path.Its all about getting a break and taking the opportunities that come your way.So best of luck to everyone today, but whatever your results, there are many opportunities and pathways into a successful career.    Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gravestone monmouth word puzzle john renie
story: Experts believe Welshman John Renie carved his own tombstone as a way of confusing the devil.Renie lived in Monmouthshire in the 1800s and died, aged 33, on May 31, 1832.His resting place is marked with what looks like some giant wordsearch puzzle, made up of 285 letters.At first glance it just looks like a random jumble of letters but the key is to start with the H in the centre and then move in any direction - except diagonally - then the message should quickly become clear.According to Find a Grave, there are 46,000 ways of spelling out the message Here lies John Renie.The writer and cleric  Lionel Fanthorpe has suggested that Renies intention may have been to confuse the devil, so ensuring him his passage to heaven.The grave is, apparently, something of an attraction at St Marys Priory Church in Monmouth, with visitors often trying to work out what it says.Renies body though no longer lies below as the stone was moved from its original position.The grave was Grade II listed in 2005, along with the memorial to Charles Heath, who died in 1831.Heath was a mayor of Monmouth and a local historian as well as antiquarian.

title: we are finally showing brussels we can go it alone after brexit and not before time
story: The publication of “technical notices” outlining how life will continue more or less as normal if the EU refuses to do a deal with Britain for petty political reasons is a crucial boost to our negotiating hand.Compare this grown-up approach to what Brussels and some European leaders have been up to recently.The EU has accused MI6 of bugging our Brexit talks. And our “ally” across the Irish Sea, the rent-a-quote Taoiseach Leo Varadkar, is threatening to ground our planes the day we leave.The silly season is coming to an end but it seems only Britain is getting serious.There is still much to do if, as we suspect, Brussels has no interest in negotiating in good faith. They are so terrified by the collapse of their project, thanks to unrest everywhere from Italy to Poland, that they’re willing to make themselves poorer as a result.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab must get his department moving quicker and force other parts of government to speed up their preparation.But we are finally showing we can go it alone. Not before time.AMAZON appear to be launching another front in their all-out war to take over just about every bit of our lives, with plans for a comparison site.This doesn’t fill us with excitement. After all, in recent days we’ve learnt that Brits are being charged over the odds for their Prime subscriptions, a service which itself has been shown not to deliver on its “next day” promises.We’ve no problem with competition or businesses doing well. Good companies with good profits create good jobs.But they must play by the rules, especially when other firms — such as high street retailers — are struggling.It is still staggering to us that Amazon’s UK tax bill FELL last year despite it almost tripling its profits.The Chancellor must close the costly loopholes that tech giants continue to exploit.WE’RE saying a little prayer for the Queen of Soul.Aretha Franklin redefined the music landscape, her songs influencing everybody from Luther Vandross to Adele.But she also raised huge amounts of money for the civil rights struggle in the US, doing it not for publicity but because she believed in it.Her extraordinary take on Otis Redding’s Respect became an anthem not just for African Americans but for feminists the world over.Rest in peace.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: china colonising smaller countries by lending them massive amounts of money they can never repay in bid for world domination
story: The country is accused of leveraging massive loans it holds over small states worldwide to snatch assets and increase its military footprint.Developing countries from Pakistan to Djibouti, the Maldives to Fiji, all owe huge amounts to China.Already there are examples of defaulters being pressured into surrendering control of assets or allowing military bases on their land.Some are calling it debt-trap diplomacy or debt colonialism - offering enticing loans to countries unable to repay, and then demanding concessions when they default.Sri Lanka provided a prime example last year.Owing more than $1billion (£786million) in debts to China, Sri Lanka handed over a port to companies owned by the Chinese government on a 99-year lease.And Djibouti, home to the US military’s main base in Africa, also looks likely to cede control of a port terminal to a Beijing-linked firm.America is eager to stop the Doraleh Container Terminal falling into Chinese hands, particularly because it sits next to Chinas only overseas military base.Last March ex-Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said Beijing encouraged dependency using opaque contracts, predatory loan practices, and corrupt deals that mire nations in debt and undercut their sovereignty.A report from The Center for Global Development offers some insight into the spreading China debt.It shows how infrastructure project loans to the likes of Mongolia, Montenegro and Laos have resulted in millions or even billions in debts, which often account for huge percentages of the countries GDPs.Many of these projects are linked to the Belt and Road initiative - a bold project to create trade routes through huge swathes of Eurasia, with China at the centre.Participating countries often undertake work on roads and ports with part-funding from China.More recently, Chinas debt empire has been rearing its head in the Pacific, prompting fears the country intends to leverage the debt to expand its military footprint into the South Pacific.Beijings creation of man-made islands in the disputed South China Sea for use as military bases suggests the concern may be warranted.In April China made these intentions more obvious - approaching Vanuatu about setting up a military base.Australia expressed alarm at this move, which would effectively increase Chinese military presence on a key gateway to Australia’s east coast, The Times reports.Vanuatu owes £191million to China, according to one think tank.Among the projects this money funded was the largest wharf in the South Pacific - considered capable of accommodating aircraft carriers.Tonga also carries some big debts and has already admitted to struggling with repayments.Tongan PM Akilisi Pohiva said on Wednesday that he was concerned Beijing was preparing to seize assets from his country.He urged other Pacific islands to join voices in calling for loan write-offs.Two loans from Chinas Export Import Bank totalling more than £91million equal a quarter of the countrys GDP.He told Australias ABC: “It has become a serious issue. We have debt distress.”Pohiva said with China debt becoming so prolific, it was no longer a problem to be dealt with individually. He added: “I think these small countries will eventually come together to find a way out.”China defended its lending practices, saying they were sincere and unselfish, and insisting it only lent to countries that could repay.Tonga is one among a list of South Pacific countries that have taken on debt in recent years.Sydney’s Lowy Institute think tank, which has closely monitored China’s activities in the Pacific, estimates Beijing has poured nearly £1.4billion into Pacific countries since 2006.Other big debtors include Papua New Guinea, which owes roughly £498million in development and aid debt, Fiji, which owes £496million, and Samoa, with debt of £181million.

title: dr pimple popper removes tail from woman
story: Taylor, 22, has had the lump, named “Lizzie the Lipoma” in between her bum cheeks since she was born but over time it grew bigger.A doctor removed the lump in 2016 but it eventually grew back.Desperate to remove the fatty deposit, which had destroyed her self-confidence, Taylor turned to Dr Pimple Popper.In the last episode of her new TV show Dr Sandra Lee sets to work trying to remove Taylor’s tail.She initially refused to operate due to how close the lipoma is to Taylor’s spinal cord – Dr Pimple Popper worried she could cause permanent nerve damage.“Theres two warning bells,” she said.“One is, why did this doctor remove this and then it came right back?“And then the other big thing for me is, a regular lipoma does not appear at birth.“You get that over time. There could be something else going on.”Dr Lee ordered an MRI scan, which shows there is a deposit of fat inside Taylors spinal cord.She offered to remove some of the bump to make it more aesthetically pleasing, but warned the procedure could disrupt Taylors spinal cord.“Even tugging on this lipoma in any way could potentially disrupt the growth within the spinal cord, and I dont want to do that in any way,” Dr Pimple Popper added.“By staying as superficial as possible Im able to shape this well and make sure it looks good without really disrupting it.”When the removal is complete, Dr Lee sews Taylor up with two to three times the normal amount of stitches to make sure the incision heals correctly.Afterwards Taylor revealed she has decided to see a neurosurgeon to see if its possible for her lipoma to be completely removed.“Im ecstatic about my results. Since my surgery with Dr Lee I feel more confident,” she said.“When I lost a part of Lizzie, there was a lot lifted off my shoulders.”A lipoma is a benign, fatty lump that grows under the skin.Theyre harmless and can usually be left alone if theyre small and painless.They are non-cancerous and are caused by an overgrowth of fat cells.Lipomas can grow anywhere on the body, but are most common on the shoulders, neck, chest, arms, back, bum and thighs.They grow very slowly and dont usually cause any problems.Lipomas dont usually need to be removed unless theyre causing problems, such as pain, or if theres uncertainty about whether its a lipoma.However it can be removed if it is large or is in an obvious place and is affecting your self-esteem.You should always see your GP if you develop a growth or swelling on your body.

title: worlds oldest cheese found in egyptian tomb and its older than jesus
story: The solidified whitish substance was found in an ancient jar and was made from a mixture of cow milk along that of a sheep or goat.In a study published this week, scientists say they have discovered that probably the most ancient archaeological solid residue of cheese ever found”.The cheese was buried in the 19th dynasty tomb of the Ptahmes, mayor of the ancient Egyptian city of Memphis.The sample was wrapped with a canvas into a broken jar, said lead author Enrico Greco, from Italys University of Catania, told the ABC.The archaeologists suspected it was a kind of food left for the owner of the tomb and they decided to ask for chemical analyses.There are several examples in mural paintings with barter scenes where cheese was represented and certainly it was used in the Egyptian medicine during the Ptolemaic period.But until now we were not sure whether it was really part of the daily life of the ancient Egyptians.The team are, however, not sure what the ancient cheese tasted like.We do not have much information on what the taste could be, we know it was made mostly from sheeps and goats milk, but for me its really hard to imagine a specific flavour, Dr Greco said.Im Italian, I love cheese and I know how much they can change in flavour and appearance even with very few differences in ingredients and process.The cheese sample was excavated at the Saqqara necropolis near Cairo between 2013 and 2014.The findings were published in the journal Analytical Chemistry this week.Scientists also found cheese contained bacteria potentially causing the deadly disease brucellosis, caught by eating unpasteurized dairy products.If confirmed, it would be the first biomolecular direct evidence of the diseases existence during the pharaonic period, according to the study.

title: indonesia earthquake sumbawa latest news
story: Tremors were felt in nearby Bali.Indonesias Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) said in a tweet there was no tsunami risk.The latest quake is the fourth to hit the south east Asian country in recent weeks that have left at least 460 dead.A massive 6.9 quake initially struck the island of Lombok which was followed by one measuring 6.4 on July 29.The epicentre of todays quake was around 500km from the island of Lombok which is still reeling from the impact of two deadly tremors and dozens of aftershocks. The vast quake struck two miles south east of Loloan in the north east of the island, at a depth of around 19 miles.Then on August 9 a third, measuring 6.2, struck.The Indonesian government reports that more than 1,400 people were injured and more than 156,000 have been displaced.Thousands of people have been left homeless and are in desperate need of food, medical care and shelter.Celebs including Take That star Gary Barlow, model Chrissy Teigen and David and Victoria Beckham were among the thousands of tourists caught up in horror scenes on the idyllic Indonesian islands when the first quake hit.

title: rare jumping spider uk first six feet
story: The crafty creepy crawlie - known as an athletic moss-dweller - was found at a nature reserve in Cheshire by an excited arachnologist.It is thought the small bog-dwellers may have survived in the UK unrecorded for thousands of years.Officially known as Sibianor larae, it was sighted by arachnologist Richard Burkmar in June.Measuring the size of half a matchstick head, the unique spiders can only just be made out with the naked eye.Mr Burkmar returned to Cheshire Wildlife Trusts Holcroft Moss Nature Reserve in Warrington with fellow arachnologist Richard Gallon and were able to find more examples of the spider, the Independent reports.Jumping spider expert then confirmed the species and that it was the first sighting in Britain.Dr Logunov had named the species after his wife Larisa Logunov following his discovery in 2001.“We were delighted to hear about all the special discoveries that have been made at our Holcroft Moss Nature Reserve,” said Cheshire Wildlife Trust’s Sarah Bennett.“The site is particularly special as it has never been exploited and cut for peat something which is unusual for most peatland in the UK.”She added: “A number of other rare bog spiders were also discovered during the surveys, including the jumping spider Heliophanus dampfi, making it the only site in England where this has been recorded.It is definitely a special site for bog-loving wildlife.”Last year the Sun reported on a Portia jumping spider using an impressive portfolio of skills to chase her prey.The Portia spider, found in every from Madagascar to Australia, is able to leap up to 50 times her own body length.

title: corbyn ally mps kicked out labour
story: Chris Williamson named a string of high-profile Labour centrists as he called for activists to get more control over whos allowed to stand for Parliament.And he suggested forcing MPs to face a vote from Labour members before every General Election - claiming it would make them more loyal to Jeremy Corbyn.Mr Williamson, the MP for Derby North, is in the middle of a two-month tour of England speaking to local branches of hard-left pressure group Momentum.At every meeting hes been drumming up support for mandatory reselection - which would give local Labour activists an iron-clad veto over whether their MPs are allowed to stand for re-election.Speaking in Plymouth last week, he said that reselection would stop a repeat of the 2016 coup against Mr Corbyn by centrist MPs who tried to replace him with Owen Smith.Mr Williamson said: Why are people so fearful of democracy? If youre doing a good job, if youre responsive to your members, then youre going to get reselected, arent you?If youre not, if youre railing against your leader, if you are disregarding your members, then members might take a different view.He added: It leads to a coup where the leader has got the biggest political mandate of any leader in this country, theres an attempt by the Westminster elites to kick him out.If people were concerned about the possibility of maybe losing their nomination through an open selection, it might just concentrate their minds a bit.The veteran leftist insisted the purpose of his democracy roadshow wasnt to campaign for deselections - but went on to name four of moderate MPs hed like to see gone.Mr Williamson said: Theres a few people I would like to see deselected - but its not up to me.I mean, if it was theyd be gone tomorrow, in fact theyd be gone yesterday. But its up to the members in each and every constituency.He continued: Im not suggesting theres going to be wholesale deselections - its not a deselection tour, contrary to what some people are saying about it or trying to characterise it as.Even though we are going to people like Chuka Umunnas seat, and Chris Leslies, and Neil Coyles, and Wes Streetings constituency.The four MPs named are all fierce critics of Mr Corbyn who have recently savaged his stance on Brexit.Mr Leslie, MP for Nottingham East, mocked Mr Williamson and suggested he was just trying to curry favour with the Labour leadership.He told The Sun: Chris should spend less time trying to get a job in the Shadow Cabinet and more time in his own Derby constituency where the Tories have been doing well in his absence.Mr Williamson quit as shadow fire minister in January after repeatedly calling for Mr Corbyn to enact even more extreme left-wing policies.And he has repeatedly stood up for leftie activists whove been thrown out of Labour following anti-Semitism claims.

title: madonna best at being madge
story: She might have had a bit of assistance to retain such a fresh-faced youthfulness, but the body is all her own work.Through hours of  gym graft and sheer willpower she’s even more bendy now than when she first burst on to the scene back in 1984 warbling Holiday in a Minnie Mouse falsetto.Madonna is the biggest-selling female artist ever, shifting 300million albums and is worth around 454million quid.She’s achieved success on her own terms and been a trailblazer for every other successful female act following in her wake. There would be no Katy Perry, Miley Cyrus or arguably Lady Gaga without Madonna.She might not be the best singer or dancer in the world, but she’s certainly the best at just being Madonna.You simply can’t imagine anyone ever telling her what to do. She’d laugh in their face.Madonna had always known how to grab attention, whether it’s publishing a book stuffed full of naked photos of herself, faking self-pleasure on stage, or kissing Britney Spears.And only Madonna could have bounced back from almost being strangled by her bright red Armani cape when she took a tumble and fell on her backside during the Brit Awards three years ago.She merely dusted herself down and carried on regardless, but I bet whoever was in charge of her wardrobe that night would have been given the b******ing of their life.Madonna is always in charge, professionally and personally. Even during her brief fling with aging lothario Warren Beatty, he was very much a bit player in the Madonna Show.That must have badly bruised the ego of a man who had always had the upper-hand in his relationships until then.It has to be said her love life hasn’t been anywhere near as successful as her career.There was a brief, destructive marriage to American actor Sean Penn in the Eighties and in 2000 she married Guy Ritchie, but the couple divorced eight years later.Since then she has dated a string of handsome and often young men, but they usually seemed to have the whiff of a photo opportunity about them rather than anything long term.She chews them up, spits them out and moves on to the next one.Madonna seems happiest as a single mum.She has uprooted the family to Lisbon, in Portugal,  because her adopted son David wants to play professional football.With her vast wealth she could easily have bought him a team such as LA Galaxy but she has always had a Calvinistic work ethic that she has tried to pass on to her kids.She has also made up with son Rocco Ritchie after a bitter custody battle and appears to be in a very good place.In an era where most young female vocalists all sound the same — bored, whiny and more than a wee bit yodelly — we really do need a one-off like Madonna.I hope she had a fabulous birthday on Thursday in Marrakech, Morocco, and danced until dawn to all of her greatest hits.Happy 60th birthday, ma’am, and I’ve no doubt you will still be in your fishnets and basques when you get that 100-year birthday message.Just when the royals and their advisers thought the whole fiasco between Meghan Markle and her dad had gone quiet, there comes a bizarre twist.Meghan’s rent-a-gob half-sister Samantha, who seethes with rage and jealousy, has announced that Thomas Markle is bringing out his own clothing range.This led to speculation as to what the brand might be called.  “Markle &amp Spencer” or “Primarkles”  (thank you, Alan Carr). But joking aside, surely this can’t be a serious  concept.Apart from being a crass, money-grabbing exercise cashing in on a quasi-royal connection, who on earth would buy garments from a pensioner who dresses like a hobo?I’ve had a great deal of sympathy for Thomas  in the past. He was treated poorly in the build-up to the  Royal Wedding, when his daughter married Prince Harry.He should have been embraced by his new family and given guidance on how to deal with the  media attention.Instead he was cast adrift. The result? Those stupid paparazzi set-up photos and a series of interviews that painted Meghan in a poor light.Every time her dad talks on TV or to newspapers and magazines, her popularity is dented.The two of them obviously have a fraught relationship. It turns out Thomas didn’t attend Meghan’s first wedding in 2011 either.Thomas increasingly comes across as bitter, angry and dislikable.To gain media attention he keeps making more and more outrageous accusations.My advice would be to stop listening to his bitchy daughter Samantha and maintain a dignified silence.All thoughts of profiteering through a clothing range or any commercial activity must be abandoned forthwith.That just might mean there could be some  sort of reconciliation in the future.Otherwise he will lose his daughter forever.ONE of the week’s most astonishing stories involved a young US woman who has been given her life back with a groundbreaking face transplant.Three years ago, Katie Stubblefield, from Mississippi in the US, tried to take her own life and shot herself in the face with a hunting rifle. She was just 18.Doctors saved her life but she was left with a mass of scar tissue instead of a face.Katie, the youngest person ever to receive a face transplant, endured more than 30 hours of surgery.Of course, the operation requires a donor – and in this case it is  a very sad story.Katie received the face  of a mum who died of a drug overdose.She was a registered organ donor and her grandmother bravely approved the donation.That decision can’t have been easy and we should always salute those who are donors, and the loved ones who give their consent.Katie won’t look like anything like her donor because the “face” is moulded on to her new bone structure.She continues to heal and  make progress, but this kind of surgery is still in its infancy.She will always look “different” but she has a second chance of life and now wants to help others in anguish and with suicidal thoughts.It’s an incredible story of despair that turned to  hope.  The skill and dedication of the team of surgeons and medics that helped her is awe-inspiring.I’m always surprised to learn that Caroline Flack is 38 years old.The presenter looks a  lot younger – and at the moment she is acting like a lovesick teenager going through the agony and ecstasy of her first serious crush.Her off/on romance with red carpet fever victim Andrew Brady is becoming laughable.This week the couple apparently had yet another spat in a London ­restaurant.If these two are to have any chance of staying together long term, they need to get out of the public eye and spend some quiet time alone.I’m sure Caroline knows of a certain Love Island that isn’t being used right now. That would do very well.The ending of the second series of The Handmaid’s Tale had me shouting in despair at my TV.I don’t want to give away too many spoilers but this cliffhanger will break your heart.It also, however, sets up season three for long overdue revenge.As always, astonishing performances from Elisabeth Moss as  June/Ofglen and Yvonne Strahovski as Serena Joy.They will soon fight it out for real when the TV actress awards are up for grabs.I’ve lost track of the amount of slippers our border terrier puppy Angus has chewed up, but this week he surpassed himself by getting his paws on his Pet Passport and virtually destroying it when we were in Spain.Luckily a  local vet issued him with a Spanish version and he now boasts dual nationality.He’s suddenly developed a liking for an afternoon siesta, but at least we were able to get him back into the UK – although who knows what will happen to him after Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: incredible images circus 250 anniversary
story: Its 250 years since the institution was born in Britain after impresario Philip Astley put on displays of tricks at his own riding school.Since then the genre has become synonymous with the shocked delight of small children and their families, enveloped in the majestic enclosure of the circus marquee - or lions den.Here we explore the bold and bizarre endeavours of the carnivalesque creation through the ages.Rare black and white photos pay testament to the enduring beauty of circus magic, while technicolour shots showcase how its evolved from a sometimes barbaric initiative to a sprawling mass of artistry.Meet the jungle tiger, the Flinstone model and a host of other extraordinary characters in this astonishing picture gallery.1915: A strongman rocks Flintstone fashion

title: thomas markle royal family scientology
story: Thomas Markle, 74, said the royals must become more modern and open to scrutiny.Speaking exclusively to The Sun at his home in Rosarito, Mexico, he said “They are either like Scientologists or the Stepford family.If they hear anybody say anything they just lock the doors. They need to speak up!“They are cult-like — like Scientology — because they are secretive.They close the door, pull the shades down and put their fingers in their ears so they don’t have to hear.“Maybe they have a secret handshake too! You cannot ask a question of them — as they won’t answer.”American Thomas has been met with a wall of silence from Kensington Palace, including Meghan, 37, since speaking out publicly about her.The Church of Scientology, founded by L Ron Hubbard, has provoked controversy for its practices and secretive methods.It has always strongly denied claims that it is a cult and that it manipulates members.The religion has attracted a huge celebrity following — including film megastars Tom Cruise and John Travolta.The Stepford Wives is a 1970s thriller novel by Ira Levin where men in American suburbia turn their spouses into brainwashed submissive robots.Thomas, an Emmy-winning lighting director, has tried to encourage Meghan and her husband Prince Harry, 33, to contact him — after three months of silence.They have not spoken since the day after the couple’s wedding at Windsor Castle.Thomas, who also has children Samantha, 53, and Tom Jnr, 51, dismissed reports that he was hoping for money from his kids.He said: “I worked hard to provide for my children. I’m their father, I don’t expect them to pay me back.”The retired Hollywood lighting director has openly criticised the Duchess in a series of interviews since her wedding.He claimed he had been completely cut off by Meghan.But people close to Meghan have insisted this is not the case.They said: His behaviour is something she has had to deal with for most of her adult life.There has been a long history of dad disappointment with her life being splattered with upset because of her relationship with him.She isnt shocked or surprised by his behaviour and dealt with it all with a lot of grace.Meghan has also come under fire from her half-sister, Samantha, who urged her to reconnect with her father.Thomas laughed off a claim that he is to launch a clothing range for men — which Meghans half sister Samantha had made in a tweet.He insisted: “It is just a joke.“The only clothes line I have is the one I hang my shirts on to dry.”He was famously pictured being measured for a suit in staged paparazzi shots in the run up to the Royal Wedding.GOT a story? RING The Sun on 0207 782 4104 or WHATSAPP on 07423720250 or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour leader commons ban tunisia wraps
story: Our revelation leaves the Labour leader facing yet more questions over his 2014 trip to Tunisia - and sparked feverish speculation among Labour MPs that it could lead to a 30-day Commons suspension.Mr Corbyn has already been reported to Parliament’s sleaze watchdog over his failure to declare who paid for the trip.Mr Corbyn spoke throughout a Commons debate on recognising Palestine on October 13 2014 - but failed to follow parliamentary rules by declaring his trip to Tunis the previous week, when he was pictured holding a wreath at the graves of those behind the massacre of 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics.Last night a Labour MP told The Sun that Mr Corbyn’s failure to disclose the visit “dramatically worsens the non-declaration” of who funded the visit.The MP compared the seriousness of the violation to the 30 day suspension given to DUP MP Ian Paisley last month after he failed to declare an all-expenses paid trip he took, courtesy of the Sri Lankan government.The MP said: “The failure to disclose this trip is big considering the 30-day ban for Ian Paisley. It has to be registered and declared when he spoke. Paisley got 30 days for the same offence.”Mr Corbyn’s office did not respond to a request for comment last night.He has refused to come clean over the costs of the controversial trip.He said he didn’t declare it in the register of MPs’ interests because it fell below the then £660 threshold for which MPs must declare hospitality they’ve received.But revelations in The Sun earlier that he stayed in a luxury 5-star hotel during the trip challenged these claims.Last night a Labour party spokesman claimed Mr Corbyn was not obligated to disclose his trip in the Palestine debate.The spokesman said: “The cost of Jeremy’s trip did not meet the threshold requiring it to be declared. Even if it had, Jeremy wouldn’t have had to declare it in every debate about the broad topic of Israel and Palestine.”GOT a story? title: danny cipriani bouncer praises pc
story: Grandad Joaquim Pereira, 63 and 5ft 8in, scuffled with the 6ft 1in lout before Jodie Botterill, 33, attempted to cuff him solo.Joaquim said: “I was surprised she confronted him on her own. She’s tiny but incredibly brave.“She should be applauded. She was very courageous and that should be recognised.“He grabbed her collar and arm. She had big bruises on her arm. He reacted badly to the frustration of the situation.”The England star, 30, also shoved the PC in the chest, pushing her over.He was led off after two other cops arrived.Fly-half Cipriani and around 20 Gloucester team-mates had earlier gone at the Little Drift club in St Helier, Jersey.Joaquim let in three as the group was too large.Cipriani saw red when the bouncer stopped him taking drinks to pals outside. Joaquim said: “I didn’t know who he was.“But he was annoyed the rest couldn’t get in.He said: “Who are you to say they can’t get in?“He tried to come out with drinks. I said it wasn’t allowed but he tried to push past me. He started abusing me.” Joaquim told the star he was turning on a camera hooked to his tie, but Cipriani snatched it.Cops later told him it was wrecked in the bust- up but that the ace would have to pay for it.Cipriani apologised to his club, team pals, fans and cops but not Joaquim. The doorman said: “He’s welcome back — for a non-alcoholic drink.”Cipriani admitted assault and resisting arrest.Jersey JPs told him to pay £2,250 in fines and compo. He faces an RFU hearing next week on an improper conduct chargeOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: public realised leopard corbyn spots
story: If Corbyn wishes to deny the obvious that is his prerogative the notion you should be prepared to swallow any and every piece of whitewashing nonsense peddled by his fans is quite a different matter.“I was present” when the wreath was laid “but I don’t think I was involved in it” is, I suppose, a step forward from the Labour party’s previous suggestion that “The Munich widows are being misled. Jeremy did not honour those responsible for the Munich killings”.Holding a wreath should not be reckoned to be any kind of endorsement of the wreath we know Jeremy deplores this kind of thing and, indeed, all other forms of wreath.Hark, though, at how quickly the approved line may shift. What was a “smear” yesterday is a forgotten truth today, airbrushed from history because, well, that’s the way these people do these things.The new line is Jeremy wants to see “a fitting memorial to everyone who died in every terrorist incident everywhere”.I dare say he’ll be visiting Enniskillen soon. Of course.And yet, in one sense there really isn’t very much to look at. Or, rather, very little that is new. This is who Corbyn is and who he has always been.He has never bothered hiding this, leaving one to assume he only does so now because there is some small, nagging part of his brain which accepts it might be sensible to do so, since failing to hide it might prove politically inconvenient.Even so, he cannot change. Anyone who has been at university will recognise Corbyn and all his fellow travellers.These were the people — some of them clever but not many of them intelligent — who fouled student politics for everyone else.The chiselling parsers and pedants and revolutionaries whose appetite for procedural minutiae bored everyone else into submission.And usually that would be that. They would, most of them, grow up eventually. But not St Jeremy and not his devotional disciples, either.They are greyer now but as instantly recognisable as they always were: Experts in room-clearing.They ought, by rights, to be confined to dingy rooms above down-at-heel pubs, where they could cut and paste their thuddingly dreary newsletters. Instead, mystifyingly, they have been given control of one of Britain’s great political parties.How much will this summer of anti-Semitism really cut through with the average voter? Less than you might think, I suspect.In the first place — and this may be a good thing — Twitter remains a niche platform and political Twitter a niche even there.Secondly, the public have already made up their minds about Corbyn and they think he’s a dud.Each month YouGov asks whether Jeremy Corbyn or Theresa May seems the best available Prime Minister and each month Corbyn trails.Sometimes he is also beaten by “Don’t know”. That’s Corbyn: He can come third in a two-horse race.But, they splutter, look at what a kind and gentle and decent man he is. Why can’t other people see that he’s a valiant activist for peace?Possibly because, for a decent fellow, he spends a startling amount of time with thoroughly indecent people.He keeps falling in with the wrong crowd while never being a member of the wrong crowd himself. There is no need here to document the long list of unsavoury people with whom Corbyn has been happy to associate himself because, really, what is now the point? He is who he is and we know who he is.In Corbyn’s world every-thing has a single, simple explanation. Colonialism is the root cause of all root causes.That insight — if we can call it that — dictated his views on Ireland just as it dictates his views on the Middle East, Cuba, Venezuela and everywhere else.From there it is but a short leap to the kind of deluded wishful thinking that animates what passes for his thinking. Once you have assumed that Northern Ireland should not exist, you absolve yourself of any and all need to think about what should happen next.You may ignore the inconvenient, and stubborn, reality that Northern Ireland — like, well, Israel — does exist and is not going to disappear.Practical politics means wrestling with things as they are, not as you think they should have been decades previously.But if you start with the theory, you may avoid practical reality. If this leaves you with nothing — precisely nothing — useful to say then so be it. You will at least remain pure in heart.If this means you are no kind of “peace campaigner” at all, that’s fine too, because you will be shielded by your own impenetrable sanctimony.As poses go, this is an awfully comfortable one but it’s not serious politics.Perhaps Corbyn really is just unlucky. But it seems more probable that he’s not. And that, far from being the decent man of legend he’s actually thoroughly indecent.The only possible alternative is that he’s thunderously, crushingly, toe-curlingly thick.On balance, however, it seems more probable that he is, in fact, both.Enough of this. Enough, already.GOT a story? RING The Sun on 0207 782 4104 or WHATSAPP on 07423720250 or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: campaigners welcome levy bottles
story: The move was announced by ministers last night.Chancellor Philip Hammond will use the Autumn Budget to introduce the levy in a bid to encourage businesses to package food in recycled plastics.He wants to avoid a direct tax on consumers such as the “Latte Levy” proposed by Environment Secretary Michael Gove.But experts warn that firms are likely to pass on any hike in production costs to customers.Carbon black plastics — used for displaying meat in super- markets — will be the most- heavily taxed. Retailers and producers would be hit for using or making “virgin plastics”.The crackdown comes after a record 162,000 responses from the public to the Government’s consultation on how to reduce single-use plastics and boost recycling.Treasury minister Robert Jenrick said: “There was clear support for a new incentive for businesses to use recycled plastics over new plastics when producing packaging — such as takeaway boxes or water bottles.“This is about using the tax system intelligently to encourage manufacturers and retailers to take more responsibility for the products that end up in shops.”Campaigners welcomed the move to place the burden for recycling on businesses.The Tories are supposed to stand up for low taxes.Across the Atlantic, President Trump has instituted tax cuts that have contributed to a booming American economy. Margaret Thatcher did the same here in the 80s.As we approach Brexit, it’s time for the Government to embrace a tax-cutting agenda that will turbo-charge the economy.GOT a story? title: young brits diabetes rocketing obesity
story: Figures show cases of the mostly preventable long-term disease, once seen only in adults in the UK, are up 41 per cent in four years.A total of 715 under-25s were treated in hospital last year, up from 507 in 2013/14 and the figure is likely to be far higher as it omits those treated by GPs.Four in five were obese. There were no cases in 1999.Type 2 typically affects overweight over-40s and can lead to blindness, heart disease, kidney failure and limb amputation.It is closely linked to a lack of exercise and poor diet. Kathryn Kirchner, of Diabetes UK, called the type 2 increase among the young “extremely worrying”.She said: “One of the most important risk factors is being overweight or obese.”Professor Graham MacGregor, of campaign group Action on Sugar, said: “These findings are a tragedy. This cannot continue.”The Local Government Association said the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health figures represented a collective failure of society to tackle childhood obesity. Eustace de Sousa, of Public Health England, added: “Bold measures are needed.“We’re working with industry to make food healthier. We’ve produced guidance for councils on planning healthier towns.“We’re campaigning to encourage people to choose healthier food and lead healthier lives.”GOT a story?
